fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let B be an algebra which is finite over the local ring A. Suppose that K(A) is infinite, or that B is local. Let n be the rank of L=B \otimes _A K(A) over K(A)=k. For B to be unramified (resp. étale) over A, it is necessary and sufficient that B be isomorphic to a quotient of (resp. isomorphic to) A[t]/FA[t], where F is a separable monic polynomial, which we can assume to be (resp. which is necessarily of) degree n.

We only have to prove necessity. Suppose that B is unramified over A, and thus that L is separable over k. It then follows from the hypotheses that L/k admits a generator \xi, and so the \xi ^i (for 0 \leq i<n) form a basis for L over k. Let u \in B be a lift of \xi; by Nakayama, the u^i (for 0 \leq i<n) generate (resp. form a basis of) the A-module B, and, in particular, we obtain a monic polynomial F \in A[t] such that F(u)=0; then B is isomorphic to a quotient of (resp. isomorphic to) A[t]/FA[t]. Finally, by applying to L/k, we see that F and F' generate A[t] modulo \mathfrak {m}A[t], and so (by Nakayama in A[t]/FA[t]) F and F' generate A[t], and we are done.
